subject: Re: [junit] Literate asserts
msgSnippet: ... It becomes very difficult to formulate expressions as soon as they are more complex than a simple equality or inequality.  It s fine for n  2 , not so
messageBody:
On 11/30/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> > Anyway, my experience with this kind of literate assertions is that it
> > scales very poorly as soon as you try to assert more than a simple
> equality
> > or a boolean
>
> Interesting, my experience is quite the oposite. Could you elaborate?


It becomes very difficult to formulate expressions as soon as they are more
complex than a simple equality or inequality. It's fine for "n > 2", not so
much for "n > 2 && n < 10" and it's all downhill from there.

The Java language also cripples this attempt by not allowing you to re-open
existing classes (you can't say n.greaterThan(2).and().lessThan(10)), so you
are forced to put your words and verbs in a certain order that is dictated
by the Java syntax, and not by the developer.

Query API's suffer from the same problem (e.g. Hibernate's Criteria API that
turns SQL expressions into typed Java objects. Nothing wrong with
Hibernate, by the way, this is a problem that's endemic to Criteria API's in
general). Past a certain complexity, you're just better off writing the
expression in terms of boolean and numeric operators, which are very easy to
parse for programmers.

, and in the end, you're probably better off simply writing a
> > method assertButtonIsEnabled(enabled) which, in my opinion, is the most
> > readable of all.
> >
>
> How does that scale better?


I didn't say it scaled better (it scales the same), I said it's the most
readable form because the programmer is free to capture the meaning of the
assertion in one word of his choosing, as opposed to literate API's which,
despite their best efforts, can't help introducing noise (such as the eq()
keyword in the example above).

One of the problems with assertXxxx(String message, Object expected,
> Object actual). Is that it is not obvious where expected and actual
> should go.


Agreed, I keep being tripped by this all the time, and I usually have to
resort to my IDE's completion capabilities to refresh my memory.

With the precence of a descriptive message and checking
> strings for equality it can become even funnier. with
> assertThat(Object actual, Expression expression) you simply can't mix
> them (unless actual is also an expression).
>
> I've noticed that a lot of people have issues with the asserThat
> syntax and I have never been able to quite figure out why.


These are just my personal objections. I don't feel extremely strongly
about this, though, I just wanted to point out that literate assertions
solve a few problems and introduce a few others, so we still haven't found
the ultimate API solution. And in the meantime, the introduction of
business-specific asserts is the best we can do.
